prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. Compute $2011 \cdot 2012 \cdot 2013 \cdot 2014$ modulo 5.
solution: Using the properties of modular arithmetic, $2011 \cdot 2012 \cdot 2013 \cdot 2014 \equiv 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 4$ modulo 5. Continuing, $1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 4 \equiv 4$ modulo 5, so $2011 \cdot 2012 \cdot 2013 \cdot 2014 \equiv \boxed{4}$ modulo 5.
gpt_response:
To compute $2011 \cdot 2012 \cdot 2013 \cdot 2014$ modulo 5, we can consider each factor individually modulo 5 and then multiply the residues together. 

First, note that $2011 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$, $2012 \equiv 2 \pmod{5}$, $2013 \equiv 3 \pmod{5}$, and $2014 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$. 

Therefore,
$$
2011 \cdot 2012 \cdot 2013 \cdot 2014 \equiv 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 4 \equiv 24 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}.
$$

So, $2011 \cdot 2012 \cdot 2013 \cdot 2014$ is congruent to 4 modulo 5.

First, note that $2011 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$, $2012 \equiv 2 \pmod{5}$, $2013 \equiv 3 \pmod{5}$, and $2014 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}$. 

Therefore,
$$
2011 \cdot 2012 \cdot 2013 \cdot 2014 \equiv 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 4 \equiv 24 \equiv 4 \pmod{5}.
$$

So, $2011 \cdot 2012 \cdot 2013 \cdot 2014$ is congruent to 4 modulo 5.
